newsitem.title: HONG KONG: US, Britain jointly urge China--preserve HK freedom.
newsitem.headline: US, Britain jointly urge China--preserve HK freedom.

text.p: Hours before the Hong Kong handover, the United States and Britain jointly urged China on Monday to maintain freedom in this Asian economic powerhouse as it comes under Beijing's control.

"We are both confident that Hong Kong can have a prosperous future and a free future if the terms of the (1984 Sino-British) Joint Declaration are adhered to," said British Foreign Secretary Robin Cook.
He spoke after conferring on the royal yacht Britannia with U.S. Secretary of State Madeleine Albright.

In particular, Cook said the two ministers remain concerned that the elected Hong Kong legislature will be disbanded at midnight and replaced with an assembly named at Beijing's direction, pending fresh elections.
Cook, Albright and British Prime Minister Tony Blair are boycotting the swearing-in ceremony although lower, but still senior-ranked, officials will be present.

The two ministers renewed calls for post-handover polls "as soon as possible." They made no reference to a reported pledge on Sunday by China's anointed Chief Executive-designate Tung Chee-hwa to hold elections by next May.
Cook also said Britain wants "a new start with Beijing ... to deal with each other as major players on the international scene and as countries that have quite a strong and developing economic link."
"Central to that relationship will be Hong Kong ... potentially a bridge not a barrier between ourselves and China," he added.

Albright, standing at the dockside with Cook for a brief news conference, joined the foreign secretary "in expressing our expectation that China will keep its word and maintain Hong Kong's autonomy and way of life for decades to come."
They repeated concerns over Beijing's decision to send in 4,000 Chinese troops hours when Hong Kong reverts at midnight to China after more than 150 years under British rule.

And Cook stressed that Chinese troops should not be seen on Hong Kong streets "where they have no place and no right" under the Basic Law, part of the legal framework that set terms for the transition of power.
But he also argued for a "proper balance" in considering the handover and the uncertainty of what Chinese control will actually mean.
"One issue that does encourage me is that there is more confidence in Hong Kong's future than any of us could necessarily have predicted five years ago," Cook said.

Albright heaped praise on Britain, saying the U.S. ally should be proud of the legacy it leaves behind in Hong Kong "one of the wonders of the world, a society that is proud, prosperous, safe and free."
